title: Alexander Altunin
text:
Alexander Terentyevich Altunin (; 14 August 1921 - 15 July 1989) was a <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet</a> general and politician.
Biography.
Alexander Altunin was born to a <a href="peasant">peasant</a> family of <a href="Russians">Russian</a> ethnicity in the village of <a href="Kalachinsky%20District">Steklyanka</a> in the <a href="Russian%20Soviet%20Federative%20Socialist%20Republic">Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic</a> (now in <a href="Omsk%20Oblast">Omsk Oblast</a>, <a href="Russian%20Federation">Russian Federation</a>).
He joined the <a href="Red%20Army">Red Army</a> in 1939 and graduated from an infantry school in <a href="Novosibirsk">Novosibirsk</a> on 10 June 1941. He joined the <a href="Kharkov%20Military%20District">Kharkov Military District</a> in the <a href="Ukrainian%20SSR">Ukrainian SSR</a> as a <a href="lieutenant">lieutenant</a> on 22 June 1941, the day of <a href="Operation%20Barbarossa">Germany's invasion of the Soviet Union</a>.
He fought in <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> and suffered wounds during the battles at <a href="Yartsevo">Yartsevo</a> (near <a href="Smolensk">Smolensk</a>) in 1941 and during the 1941-1942 <a href="Battle%20of%20the%20Kerch%20Peninsula">Battle of the Kerch Peninsula</a>. He caught <a href="typhus">typhus</a> while recovering from the latter wound in a military hospital in 1942 and subsequently served as a company training officer in the <a href="Volga%20Military%20District">Volga Military District</a> from April 1942. He joined the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20the%20Soviet%20Union">Communist Party of the Soviet Union</a> and rejoined the front lines in 1943.
Altunin received the title <a href="Hero%20of%20the%20Soviet%20Union">Hero of the Soviet Union</a> in 1944, having organized the establishment of a foothold across the <a href="Vistula">Vistula</a> during the <a href="Lvov-Sandomierz%20Offensive">Lvov-Sandomierz Offensive</a> and led his men in tenaciously fighting off the German counterattack while distracting them from the Soviet troops' main landing point.
Promoted to <a href="major%20%28rank%29">major</a> in November 1944, Altunin was sent to <a href="Frunze%20Military%20Academy">Frunze Military Academy</a> in <a href="Bishkek">Bishkek</a> in March 1945 and graduated in 1948. He served in the <a href="Turkestan%20Military%20District">Turkestan Military District</a> in the <a href="Uzbek%20SSR">Uzbek SSR</a> 1948-1955 and graduated from the <a href="General%20Staff%20Academy%20%28Russia%29">Academy of the General Staff</a> in 1957.
He served as commander of the <a href="North%20Caucasus%20Military%20District">North Caucasus Military District</a> from June 1968 to October 1970. He was elected to the <a href="Supreme%20Soviet%20of%20the%20Soviet%20Union">Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union</a> and made head of the personnel department of the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Defense%20of%20the%20USSR">Ministry of Defense of the USSR</a> in 1970.
Altunin became a deputy minister of defense and director of the <a href="Civil%20Defense%20Forces%20of%20the%20USSR">Civil Defense Forces of the USSR</a>, the Soviet Union's <a href="civil%20defense">civil defense</a> and <a href="emergency%20management">emergency management</a> program, in 1972, as a <a href="colonel-general">colonel-general</a>. He joined the <a href="Central%20Committee%20of%20the%20Communist%20Party%20of%20the%20Soviet%20Union">Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union</a> in 1976 and was promoted to <a href="General%20of%20the%20Army%20%28Soviet%20Union%29">General of the Army</a> in February 1977, but was replaced as head of the Civil Defense Forces by <a href="Vladimir%20Govorov">Vladimir Govorov</a> after the 1986 <a href="Chernobyl%20disaster">Chernobyl disaster</a> and instead appointed a member of the <a href="Group%20of%20Inspectors%20General">Group of Inspectors General of the Ministry of Defense</a>.
Altunin was the author of publications dealing with civil defense as well as several works based on his experiences as a World War II officer.
He died in <a href="Moscow">Moscow</a> on 15 July 1989 and was interred at <a href="Novodevichy%20Cemetery">Novodevichy Cemetery</a>.
